title-group.article-title: Dietary Folate Deficiency in Pseudopregnant Mice Has No Effect on Homeobox A10 Promoter Methylation or Expression

contrib-group.aff: 1Laboratory of Reproductive Biology, Chongqing Medical University, Chongqing, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Yubin Ding, Chongqing Medical University, Box 197, No.1 Yixueyuan Rd, Chongqing, 400016, People’s Republic of China Email: dingyb@gmail.com

abstract.p: During the reproductive cycle, a number of genes controlling endometrial changes are regulated by DNA methylation, a common epigenetic modification. Because dietary folate affects DNA methylation, we determined whether a folate-deficient diet (FDD) alters DNA methylation in endometria of pseudopregnant mice, focusing on the homeobox A10 (Hoxa10) promoter. Mice were given an FDD or control diet for 40 to 45 days and examined on day 5 of pseudopregnancy. Compared to control mice, FDD mice had lower folate levels in liver and serum (P = .004). However, the FDD did not significantly affect DNA methylation within the cytosine–guanine dinucleotide (CpG)-rich Hoxa10 promoter, even when specific CpG sites were examined (P > .05). In endometrial tissue sections, the localization of anti-Hoxa10 staining was unchanged in FDD mice. Therefore, folate deficiency did not significantly affect promoter methylation or expression of Hoxa10.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: DNA methylation is known to be involved in the regulation of genes involved in the establishment of a receptive endometrium (eg, those involved in estrogen and progesterone signaling). 1 For example, expression of estrogen receptor 2 in the human endometrium is downregulated by promoter methylation. 1 Two genetic markers for decidualization, prolactin and insulin-like growth factor binding protein 1, are both upregulated in human endometrial stromal cells when demethylated by nucleotide substitutions using 5-aza-2-deoxycytidine. 2 As the receptive endometrium is established, E-cadherin is also regulated by DNA methylation. 3 Additionally, the promoter of homeobox A10 (Hoxa10), another established marker for decidualization, is hypermethylated in the endometrium of women using intrauterine devices. 4 Consistent with these observations, the expression levels of DNA (cytosine-5-) methyltransferases 1, 3a, and 3b (DNMT1, DNMT3A, and DNMT3B) vary according to the phase of the menstrual cycle, further suggesting that DNA methylation may regulate gene expression in the endometrium to facilitate embryo implantation. 5,6

Folate is an essential factor in modulating methylation of cytosine–guanine dinucleotides (CpGs) within DNA. It is utilized for the synthesis of S-adenosylmethionine, which is the primary methyl group donor for most methylation reactions. 7,8 Folate deficiency can lead to both hypo- and hypermethylation of DNA. 9 DNA hypomethylation can contribute to cancer development via several mechanisms, including reactivation of gene expression and promotion of chromosomal instability. Hypermethylation typically occurs at CpG islands within promoter sequences, thereby inactivating tumor suppressor genes. 7,9
–15

Folate deficiency is also associated with various reproductive disorders, including spontaneous abortion and recurrent loss of pregnancy. 16 –18 It is unknown, however, whether diminished levels of folate alter expression of critical genes in the endometrium by modifying methylation. In the present study, we established a folate-deficient mouse model to determine whether folate deficiency affects promoter methylation and expression of Hoxa10, the mouse homolog of Hoxa10, which is also vital for decidualization in the mouse endometrium on day 5 of pregnancy.

sec.title: Animals and Treatment
sec.p:
All experiments were approved by the Animal Care and Use Committee of Chongqing Medical University (No. 20110016). Female Kunming mice (8 weeks old, 20-24 g) were obtained from the Laboratory Animal Center of Chongqing Medical University (Certificate: SCXK(YU) 2007-0001, Chongqing, China). Animals were randomly divided into 2 groups: control and folate deficient (n = 30 each). All mice were fed an identical diet (Research Diets, New Brunswick, New Jersey), except that controls received 2 mg folate/kg and folate-deficient mice received 0 mg folate/kg for 35 days. This folate-deficient diet (FDD) effectively reduces folate levels in rodent organs and has been used previously for studies on folate and DNA methylation. 15,19
–23 Mice with roughly equivalent body weights were chosen from both groups. To minimize the effects of embryos on the endometrium, females were mated overnight with vasectomized males to induce pseudopregnancy. Vasectomized males were from the same strain and were fed the same control diet (CTR). The next day was designated day 1 of pseudopregnancy if a vaginal plug was detected during a morning (0800 hours) examination. Only mice that became pseudopregnant within 5 days of mating were selected for further experimentation. The 2 groups (n = 12 each) continued to receive their respective diets until day 5 of pseudopregnancy, when the animals were sacrificed. This time point was chosen because endometrial changes that are important for embryo implantation, such as establishment of a receptive uterus and decidualization, are known to occur on day 5 of pregnancy in the mouse. At the time of sacrifice, therefore, mice had received the control or experimental diet for 40 to 45 days. After sacrifice, the endometria were removed and snap frozen in liquid nitrogen. Left uteri were removed and embedded in paraffin. Folate levels in serum and liver samples were determined by high-performance liquid chromatography. 24

sec.title: RNA Isolation and Quantitative Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction
sec.p: Total RNA was extracted from tissue samples of CTR and FDD group (n = 6 each) using the TRIZol method (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, California). Total RNA (0.1 µg) from each sample was treated with DNase and converted to complementary DNA (cDNA) using the PrimeScript RT Reagent kit (TaKaRa, Dalian, China). Messenger RNA (mRNA) levels were evaluated using the iQ5 Real-Time PCR Detection System (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Foster City, California) with SYBR Premix Ex Taq II (Takara). The primers for Hoxa10 (NM_008263) and β-actin (Actb; NM_007393.3) are listed in Table 1. Primers were designed using Primer Premier v5.0 (Premier Biosoft, Palo Alto, California) and synthesized by Sangon Biotechnology (Shanghai, China). Quantitative polymerase chain reaction (Q-PCR) was carried out at 95°C for 10 minutes, followed by 40 cycles of 95°C for 30 seconds (denaturing), 56°C for 30 seconds (annealing), and 72°C for 45 seconds (extension). Reactions were performed in triplicate and products were subjected to melting curve analysis and visualized on an agarose gel to confirm size. Relative gene expression levels were calculated using the 2–ΔΔCt method.

fn.p: Abbreviations: Q-PCR, quantitative polymerase chain reaction; MSP, methylation-specific PCR; BSP, bisulfite sequencing PCR; Hoxa10, homeobox A10.

sec.title: Western Blot Analysis
sec.p: Protein was extracted from endometrial tissues of CTR and FDD group (n = 6 each) using the Mouse/Rat Tissue Extract Protein Array kit (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, Missouri). Samples were boiled in 5× SDS sample loading buffer for 10 minutes. Equal amounts of protein (30 µg) were separated by 10% sodium dodecyl sulfate–polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and transferred to nitrocellulose membranes (Bio-Rad Laboratories). Membranes were incubated in blocking buffer (37°C for 2 hours) followed by rabbit polyclonal anti-β-actin or goat polyclonal anti-Hoxa10 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, California) in blocking buffer (1:100; 4°C overnight). After washing, blots were incubated with horseradish peroxidase–conjugated secondary antibodies against goat or rabbit (Zhongshan Goldenbridge, Beijing, China) in blocking buffer (37°C for 1 hour). After additional washes, immunoreactive bands were visualized using enhanced chemiluminescence reagents (Beyotime, Shanghai, China). Densitometry measurements were analyzed using Quantity One v4.4.0 (Bio-Rad Laboratories). Protein expression levels were normalized to β-actin.

sec.title: Genomic DNA Extraction and Bisulfite Modification
sec.p: Frozen tissue samples from CTR and FDD groups (n = 8 each) were digested with proteinase K (50°C overnight), and genomic DNA was extracted using a standard DNeasy Blood and Tissue kit (Qiagen, Valencia, California). Genomic DNA samples (1 mg) were treated with bisulfate using the Methylamp DNA Modification Kit (Epigentek, Brooklyn, N ew York, USA) to convert unmethylated cytosines to uracil. Bisulfite-modified DNA was dissolved in 20 µL water and stored at –80°C.

sec.title: Methylation-Specific PCR
sec.p: Sodium bisulfite-treated DNA (200 ng) from each participants of 2 groups (n = 8) was analyzed by methylation-specific PCR (MSP) using primer sets specific for the Hoxa10 promoter. The 394 bp immediately upstream of the transcriptional start site were chosen for this analysis because this region is particularly susceptible to methylation in uterine tissue (Figure 1). 25,26 Primers were designed using MethPrimer (Table 1) 27 and synthesized by Sangon Biotechnology. Polymerase chain reaction was carried out at 94°C for 4 minutes, followed by 35 cycles of 94°C for 30 seconds (denaturing), T m (50°C-58°C) for 30 seconds (annealing), T m + 2°C for 30 seconds (secondary annealing), and 72°C for 45 seconds (extension). A final extension step of 72°C for 5 minutes was performed. Polymerase chain reaction products were analyzed on a 1.5% agarose gel and visualized using ethidium bromide.

caption.p: Structure of the mouse Hoxa10 gene. An enlarged view of the 394-bp promoter region used for methylation analysis shows the transcriptional start site (TSS) and 21 CpG sites (purple dashes). Dark and light green boxes denote CpG islands associated with the coding region of Hoxa10. Blue boxes indicate exons of 2 Hoxa10 splice variants. PCR indicates polymerase chain reaction; Hoxa10, homeobox A10; CpG, cytosine–guanine dinucleotide

sec.title: Bisulfite Sequencing PCR
sec.p: For bisulfite sequencing PCR (BSP), the AmpliTaq Gold PCR Master Mix (Applied Biosystems, Carlsbad, California) was used, with 8 µL bisulfite-treated DNA of each participant from 2 groups (n = 6) in a reaction volume of 50 µL. Primers for Hoxa10 are listed in Table 1. Polymerase chain reaction was carried out at 98°C for 4 minutes, followed by 20 cycles of 94°C for 45 seconds, 66°C (−0.5°C each cycle) for 45 seconds, and 72°C for 1 minute. A final incubation at 72°C for 7 minutes was performed. The first-stage PCR product was then amplified using 20 additional cycles of 94°C for 45 seconds, 56°C for 45 seconds, and 72°C for 1 minute. A final incubation at 72°C for 8 minutes was performed. The PCR products (394 bp) were purified using the QIAquick PCR purification kit (Qiagen) and sequenced by Sangon Biotechnology.

sec.title: Immunohistochemistry
sec.p: Uterine samples from 2 groups (n = 6 each) were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde and embedded in paraffin. Sections of 4 µm were deparaffinized and dehydrated using a graded series of xylene and alcohol. For antigen retrieval, sections were boiled for 15 minutes in 0.01 mol/L sodium citrate buffer. After cooling in the buffer for 60 minutes at room temperature, the sections were transferred to 0.3% H2O2/methanol for 30 minutes to inactivate endogenous peroxidases. After washing 3 times in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) with 0.1% Tween 20, the sections were incubated in blocking buffer (PBS/Tween plus 5% normal rabbit serum; 30 minutes at room temperature), followed by goat polyclonal anti-Hoxa10 (1:50; 4°C overnight). After washing, the sections were incubated with secondary antibody against goat (1 hour room temperature), and the signal was amplified using avidin–biotin (Zhongshan Goldenbridge). After incubation with diaminobenzidine (DAB; Zhongshan Goldenbridge), the sections were counterstained with hematoxylin. Negative control sections were incubated with nonimmune serum rather than primary antibody. Signal intensity was classified as weak/no staining, moderate, or strong.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Western blot analysis, MSP, and Q-PCR were repeated 3 times independently for each group. Differences between the 2 groups were analyzed using the Student t test, Wilcoxon rank sum test, or 2-sided Fisher exact test. Differences were considered statistically significant if P < .05.

sec.title: Folate-Deficient Diet Reduced Serum and Liver Folate Levels
sec.p: At day 5 of pseudopregnancy, serum folate levels were significantly lower in mice fed an FDD compared to the CTR (2.76 ± 0.82 [FDD] vs 15.43 ± 2.22 ng folate/mL; n = 12 each, P = .018). Folate levels in the liver were similarly affected (2.85 ± 0.54 [FDD] vs 13.63 ± 2.26 µg folate/g; n = 12 each; P = .004). Feeding mice an FDD for 40 to 45 days, therefore, resulted in significant folate depletion.

sec.title: The FDD Did Not Significantly Affect Methylation of the Hoxa10 Promoter
sec.p: To investigate whether an FDD affects the methylation status of the Hoxa10 promoter in mouse endometrium, we used MSP to amplify the CpG-rich region associated with the Hoxa10 transcriptional start site. At day 5 of pregnancy, this region accounts for most transcriptional regulation of Hoxa10. 25,26 The MSP analysis of control endometrial samples generated bands associated with both methylated and unmethylated DNA (Figure 2). No control mice had only unmethylated bands. Similar results were obtained for the FDD group, as 87.5% (7 of 8 mice) had bands associated with both methylated and unmethylated DNA (P = 1.00 compared to control). Only 1 FDD mouse had unmethylated bands. Thus, folate deficiency did not significantly affect the methylation frequency of the Hoxa10 promoter.

caption.p: Methylation-specific PCR analysis of the Hoxa10 promoter. Bisulfite-converted DNA samples from endometria of mice fed a folate-deficient diet (FDD, n = 8) or control diet (CTR, n = 8) were analyzed. Lanes-labeled M and U contain reaction products from primers specific for methylated and unmethylated CpG sites, respectively. Within M lanes, the faint or absent bands indicate partial or undetectable methylation. The frequency of Hoxa10 promoter methylation was 100% (CTR) and 87.5% (FDD). PCR indicates polymerase chain reaction; Hoxa10, homeobox A10; CpG, cytosine–guanine dinucleotide.

sec.p: To examine the methylation frequency more precisely, we used BSP to quantitatively assess the methylation status of each of the 21 CpG sites in the Hoxa10 promoter (Figure 3). We randomly selected 5 clones of the promoter from each of the 6 mice, resulting in 30 BSP analyses for each treatment group (Figure 3C). In total, 630 CpG sites (30 × 21) were analyzed in each experimental group. We found 40 (6.35%) methylated CpG sites in FDD samples, compared to 41 (6.51%) methylated sites in controls (P = 1.00). Therefore, the overall levels of methylation within this promoter sequence did not differ between FDD and control mice. Furthermore, when CpG sites were examined individually, no trends were detected, as only insignificant changes in methylation levels (P > .05) were observed at each of the 21 CpG sites (Figure 3D). Folate deficiency, therefore, induced only random changes in methylation within the Hoxa10 promoter that were not site specific.

caption.p: Bisulfite sequencing of the Hoxa10 promoter. Bisulfite-modified genomic DNA from endometria of mice fed either a folate-deficient diet (FDD, n = 6) or a control diet (CTR, n = 6) were analyzed. A, Sequence of the Hoxa10 promoter region from −386bp to +8bp (the transcriptional start site). Numbers 1 to 21 represent CpG sites, red arrows represent locations of sequencing primers, and the bold black arrow indicates the direction of transcription. B, Representative sequences of partial promoter in CTR and FDD mice. Sodium bisulfite treatment of DNA converts unmethylated cytosines (C) to thymines (T) after subsequent PCR, but methylated C remain unchanged by the treatment. Methylated and unmethylated CpG sites are indicated by red and black arrows, respectively. C, Individual results for methylation status at each of the 21 CpG sites. Each row represents a single DNA clone (5 clones per mouse). Each circle represents a single CpG site. Filled and open circles indicate methylated and unmethylated cytosines, respectively. A total of 41 methylated CpGs were detected in the CTR group (n = 6), whereas 40 methylated CpGs were detected in the FDD group (n = 6). D, Distribution of methylated CpGs within the Hoxa10 promoter. Graphical representation of data from panel C, showing the number of methylated CpGs (y axis) at each of the 21 sites (x axis). No significant methylation differences were detected between the FDD and CTR groups (P > .05 at each site). “×” indicates DNA that was not sequenced; Hoxa10, homeobox A10; CpG, cytosine–guanine dinucleotide.

sec.title: The FDD Did Not Affect Hoxa10 Expression
sec.p: We next evaluated Hoxa10 expression in the endometrium. Quantitative PCR analysis revealed no significant differences in Hoxa10 mRNA levels between FDD and control mice (P = .148; Figure 4A). Hoxa10 protein levels were also similar between the 2 groups (P = .361), as revealed by Western blot analysis (Figure 4B). Finally, we used immunohistochemistry to examine Hoxa10 localization within endometrial tissue on day 5 of pseudopregnancy. High levels of Hoxa10 were detected in stromal cells, whereas only low levels were detected in both luminal and glandular epithelial. Compared to controls, FDD samples exhibited slightly reduced levels of staining intensity but no change in distribution (Figure 4C).

caption.p: Hoxa10 expression in the endometria of mice fed a folate-deficient diet (FDD, n = 6) or control diet (CTR, n = 6). A, Q-PCR was used to determine the levels of Hoxa10 mRNA in CTR and FDD samples. B, Western blot analysis of Hoxa10 protein levels. C, Immunostaining for Hoxa10 in representative endometrial samples. le indicates luminal epithelia; ge, glandular epithelia; s, stroma; Hoxa10, homeobox A10; Q-PCR, quantitative polymerase chain reaction; mRNA, messenger RNA. Scale bar, 50 μm.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Folate depletion can arise from dietary deficiency or aberrant folate metabolism and is associated with the development and progression of many pathological states. 7,16,17,28 It is not known, however, whether a dietary deficiency affects DNA methylation or whether such an affect in turn regulates the expression of genes that control decidualization in the endometrium. Addressing this question is extremely difficult, as both ethical and practical barriers prevent the acquisition of relevant human tissues. Because the effects of moderate folate deficiency in rodents are quite similar to those in humans, 29 we generated folate-deficient pseudopregnant mice to measure changes in DNA methylation of the Hoxa10 promoter and changes in Hoxa10 expression in the endometrium. A change in the methylation status of the Hoxa10 promoter could serve as a marker for women at risk of folate deficiency.

Hoxa10 is critical for implantation and decidualization. The Hoxa10 promoter is susceptible to methylation, as evidenced by the hypermethylation observed in the endometria of women using an intrauterine device 2 and in the uteri of mice exposed to diethylstilbestrol. 26 We measured the effects of dietary folate deficiency on methylation of the Hoxa10 promoter in mice but did not detect any significant changes, even when all 21 individual CpG sites in the 394-bp region immediately upstream of the transcriptional start site were analyzed. Similar results have been obtained in the rat colon, where folate deficiency does not alter global patterns of DNA methylation 22 or methylation associated with the Myc gene. 30 However, moderate folate depletion in cultured colon cells and rat tissues causes site-specific hypomethylation, 31 –33 whereas folate depletion in rat adult liver and preneoplastic liver causes DNA hypermethylation 21 and de novo methylation of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2A. 34 How folate deprivation can produce such paradoxical results remains unclear.

DNA methyltransferases, including Dnmt1, Dnmt3a, and Dnmt3b, are key mediators of DNA methylation, and their expression is affected by dietary deficiency in mice as well as dietary supplementation in humans. 35,36 Expression of DNA methyltransferases in the mouse uterus during early pregnancy and susceptibility to dietary folate deficiency YB Ding, JL He, XQ Liu, XM Chen, CL Long, YX Wang. Hence, reduced levels of DNA methylation that are associated with folate deficiency may be affected by the catalytic enzymes Dnmt1 and Dnmt3a. 11,12

Hoxa10 is expressed in the endometrium at the time of embryo implantation in response to estrogen or progesterone. 37,38 Conditions such as endometriosis, 39 adenomyosis, 40 and exposure to diethylstilbestrol 26 have all been shown to alter Hoxa10 expression. Here, we have shown that Hoxa10 levels (both mRNA and protein) were unchanged in folate-deficient mice compared with controls. These findings suggest that folate depletion does not significantly affect the Hoxa10 promoter or Hoxa10 expression in pseudopregnant mice. In addition, it is unlikely that folate deficiency affected DNA methylation of other CpG-rich regulatory regions associated with Hoxa10, 25,26 because no difference in Hoxa10 expression was detected between FDD and control mice.

In summary, our results indicate that a short-term dietary folate deficiency leads to folate deprivation in pseudopregnant mice but has no significant effect on promoter methylation or expression of the Hoxa10 gene. Additional studies examining the impact of folate deficiency on DNA methylation and pregnancy are warranted.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank Prof Xiaoqiu Xiao for helpful suggestions and Prof Qing Zeng for assistance with the statistical analysis.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: The study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (30700898, and 30973195), the Natural Science Foundation Project of CQ CSTC (2009BA5082, 2009BB5271, and 2011jjA10085), and the Excellent Doctoral Dissertation funding of Chongqing Medical University. The funders played no role in the study’s design, the collection or analysis of data, the decision to publish, or the preparation of the manuscript.
